newsitem.title: FINLAND: Polish premier says joining EU, NATO inseparable.
newsitem.headline: Polish premier says joining EU, NATO inseparable.

text.p: Polish Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz said on Monday that Poland sees membership in NATO and the European Union as inseparable.

"We do not want to separate those two issues. We believe, from our perspective, those are two elements of the same process of joining European transatlantic structures," Cimoszewicz told a news conference with Finnish Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen.
"We believe both (EU and NATO) are structures that may help us to exist in a stable and democratic Europe," Cimoszewicz said.
Cimoszewicz and Lipponen also discussed European and Baltic security and signed an updated treaty on mutual investment.
Non-aligned Finland joined the EU alongside Sweden and Austria at the start of 1995. It is not seeking NATO membership, but has joined NATO's Partnership for Peace (PfP).

Cimoszewicz said Poland was watching with concern its neighbour Belarus, where voters in Sunday's referendum supported a draft constitution that would expand the powers of President Alexander Lukashenko.
"We hope that all eventual changes in their constitutional system will go according to the existing constitution and existing ... procedures," Cimoszewicz said.
